12. Specializations of the Apical Surface I: Microvilli
13. Specializations of the Apical Surface II: Cilia

previous next to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages, swipe right or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe left or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. using the emodule h1 epithelia 1. references 2. objectives 3. introduction

previous start with age, wear and tear, info an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus…. information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below: conventions used in the emodule some slides contain the “slide talk” icon on the title bar. click this icon to hear me explain or elaborate on slide content. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related slides. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition or explanation. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should make a point of becoming familiar. some slides contain the icon which means that you are within a “layer” of the original slide, simply click this button in order to navigate back to the original layer of the slide.

h1 epithelia: references previous next images from wheater’s functional histology 5th ed., © 2006 by young et al. denoted by “w”. images from junqueira’s basic histology, text & atlas, 14th ed., by mescher © 2016, mcgraw-hill denoted by “j”. images from histology: a text and atlas, 7th ed., by pawlina, © 2016 wolters kluwer health denoted by “p”. images from netter’s functional histology, 2nd ed., by ovalle & nahirney, © 2013 by saunders denoted by “n”. images from human anatomy 3rd ed., © 2015 by mckinley and o’loughlin, denoted by “mc”. images from textbook of histology, 4th ed., by gartner, © 2017 by elsevier denoted by “g”. recommended online resources: university of minnesota histology guide university of leeds histology guide university of michigan virtual microscopy western university virtual slide box university of illinois cell and tissue biology

h1 objectives next previous 2 when you have learned the material presented here, you will be able to: describe where epithelia are located in the body. describe the structural characteristics of the various classes of epithelia. describe the functions associated with the different types of epithelia. describe the relationship of exocrine and endocrine glands to epithelia. describe the structural modifications found in different epithelia and how they relate to function. describe understand and apply the classification system of epithelia. describe the logic behind the structure / function relationship of epithelia in different locations in the body. identify the various classes of epithelia, their cell types and specializations.
next previous h1 introduction to epithelia 3 where in the body is epithelia found? what are the general characteristics of epithelia? what, in general, are its functions?

next previous h1 where? epithelia covers “free” body surfaces 4 the external body surface is lined by an epithelium: called epidermis, a component of skin internal body surfaces are lined by epithelia: epithelium lines internal passageways that open to the exterior, e.g. the digestive, genitourinary, and respiratory tracts. combined with its underlying ct, these epithelia form mucous membranes. epithelia lining vessels (arteries, veins, heart chambers, lymphatic vessels) is called endothelium. epithelia lining internal body cavities that do not open to the exterior (pleural, pericardial and peritoneal cavities) is called mesothelium. combined with its underlying ct, mesothelia forms serous membranes: these are the pleura, pericardia and peritoneum these are “covering epithelia”; covering epithelium is classified as either: simple epithelia: 1 layer of cells stratified epithelia: >1 layer of cells

jxn jxn h1 characteristics of epithelia next previous 5 cellularity: this tissue consists of densely-packed cells with little material between them (unlike ct) polarity: apical, lateral & basal surface specializations allow each surface to perform specific functions specialized intercellular junctions (jxn) join cells to each other and to underlying tissue to provide stability or to allow selective molecular movement through an epithelial sheet avascular but innervated : note in the diagram that the nerves (yellow) run through the underlying ct and innervate the epithelial sheet with sensory fibres; however the blood vessels (red and blue) do not cross the basement membrane; epithelial cells rely on diffusion for nutrient delivery and waste removal regeneration, by mitosis, of cells lost at the epithelial surface; e.g. skin cells shed from the body surface attachment to basement membrane (bm) & underlying connective tissue (ct) avascular but innervated : note in the diagram that the nerves (yellow) run through the underlying ct and innervate the epithelial sheet with sensory fibres; however the blood vessels (red and blue) do not cross the basement membrane; epithelial cells rely on diffusion for nutrient delivery and waste removal regeneration, by mitosis, of cells lost at the epithelial surface; e.g. skin cells shed from the body surface attachment to basement membrane (bm) & underlying connective tissue (ct)

h1 functions of epithelia a b next previous 6 a given epithelium is structurally specialized to perform a specific function, based on the requirements of its location: physical protection, e.g.against abrasion, dehydration,chemical, microbial attack controlled permeability as determined by epithelial structure; any substance that enters the body must cross an epithelium transcellular (a) vs. paracellular (b) molecular transport provide sensation, including general (touch, temp, pain, etc.) and special senses (vision, hearing, balance, smell, etc.) produce specialized secretions (glandular epithelia: e.g. salivary glands, sweat glands, pituitary gland, pancreas, etc.)

next previous h1 glandular epithelia 7 endocrine and exocrine glands are derived from epithelia, but specialized to produce and secrete their cell product. endocrine and exocrine glands may be multicellular or unicellular

both covering epithelia and glandular epithelia develop from simple sheets: next previous h1 development of glandular epithelia 8 exocrine glands secrete outward onto an epithelial surface via a duct secretoryportion duct proliferating cells burrow into underlying ct simple epithelium basement membrane connective tissue disappearanceof connectionto free surface covering epithelia simple stratified j4.19 glandular epithelia capillaries secretoryportion endocrine glands secrete inward, into the surrounding tissue fluid. their product, a hormone, is delivered to its target tissue by the cardiovascular system.

e ct bm mucous n n n n n n n n n n next previous h1 exocrine glands may be unicellular: goblet cells 9 goblet cells are unicellular, mucous-secreting, exocrine glands interspersed amongst epithelial cells secrete mucous across their apical aspect onto the exposed surface of an epithelial sheet to protect the cells of the covering epithelia e.g. respiratory epithelium, where it traps inhaled particles; the mucous (and particles) are cleared from the respiratory tract e.g. digestive tract , where it lubricates surfaces to ease passage of contents *n = nucleus

a b next previous h1 endocrine glands may be unicellular 11 *n = nucleus may exist within some covering epithelia as diffuse neuroendocrine cells, inc. the enteroendocrine (ee) cells of the digestive tract secrete their cell products across their basal aspect into the tissue fluid of underlying ct their cell products may influence adjacent cells (paracrine signaling), e.g. with stomach filling, gastrin, secreted by ee cells in its epithelial lining, influences adjacent cells to secrete acid, aiding digestion their cell products may be taken up by underlying bvs for systemic distribution (endocrine signaling) e.g. cholecystokinin (cck) secreted by ee cells in the small intestine stimulates the release of digestive hormones from the pancreas and bile from the gall bladder

next previous h1 covering epithelia 11 epithelia cover body surfaces, inside and out. different surfaces serve different functions. structural specializations tailor an epithelia to its location and function.

 surface area of epithelia that function in absorption , secretion minimally-motile, finger-like extensions of apical surface core: actin microfilaments cross-linked to each other, to the membrane, and to the terminal web number of microvilli on the apical cell surface is proportional to the rate at which molecules move through the apical cell membrane short, sparse microvilli in tissues involved in low rates of molecular transfer tall, densely-packed microvilli in tissues involved in high rates of molecular transfer especially well-developed in the small intestine and kidney. next previous h1 specializations of the apical surface i: microvilli 12

next previous h1 specializations of the apical surface ii: cilia 13 found on epithelia specialized to move fluid along their luminal surface highly motile, synchronized, finger-like extensions of apical cell membrane core: microtubules with associated proteins, inc. dynein taller than microvilli very well developed in respiratory epithelia and uterine tubes the tails of sperm are structurally similar to the core of a cilia, and this underlies the mobility of sperm; men with ciliary dyskinesia may have immotile sperm.

anchoring junctions provide mechanical strength and the ability to withstand shear forces attach the cytoskeletons of adjacent epithelial cells to each other across their lateral membranes attach the cytoskeletons of epithelial cells across their basal surfaces to the underlying bm and ct occluding junctions block the intercellular space, and thereby control paracellular molecular movement communicating junctions control ionic / molecular movement between adjacent epithelial cells next previous h1 intercellular junctions jxn jxn 14 epithelial cells attach to each other & to underlying tissue, forming a functional unit these contacts are present in other tissues, but most prominent in epithelia different types of attachments serve different purposes… functional classes of intercellular junctions:

next previous h1 anchoring cells to each other: zonula adherens 15 zonule means “belt”; zonula adherens (za) entirely surrounds cells, like a belt around your waist, binding cells together in all directions; think of a six-pack za link the actin microfilament network of the cytoskeleton of adjacent cells; esp. well developed in the small intestine the transmembrane proteins that link across the intercellular space are cadherins present throughout an epithelial sheet; effectively links the actin microfilament network of all cells, thus distributing any applied shear forces throughout the entire sheet g5.11

do not form belts; they are arranged more like rivets or spot-welds, here and there, joining the lateral surfaces of the cells desmosomes link the intermediate filament network of the cytoskeleton of adjacent cells;esp. well developed in the skin like za, the transmembrane proteins that link across the intercellular space are cadherins present throughout an epithelial sheet; effectively linking the intermediate filament network of all cells, thus distributing shear forces throughout the entire sheet the more there are, the more strongly the cells are bound together next previous h1 anchoring cells to each other: desmosomes 16 g5.11

next previous h1 anchoring epithelia to underlying tissue: hemidesmosomes 17 as the name suggests, is like half a desmosome links the intermediate filament network (a) of the cytoskeleton of epithelial cells across their basal surface to underlying bm (b); esp. well developed in the skin unlike za or desmosomes, the transmembrane proteins that link to molecules of the bm across the extracellular space are integrins (c) present throughout an epithelial sheet; binds the epithelium to underlying tissue, thus resisting their separation the more there are, the stronger the epithelium is bound down g5.11

next previous h1 control of paracellular molecular movement: tight junctions 18 integral transmembrane glycoproteins arranged as branching, anastomosing strips bound to similar proteins in the adjacent cell membrane aka zonula occludens, because they are arranged in a belt-like fashion, all around the cell seal the paracellular space around the circumference of cells, controlling molecular movement between cells anatomical basis of functional tissue compartments, e.g. blood-brain barrier, blood-testis barrier, blood-thymus barrier g5.11

next previous h1 control of intercellular molecular movement: gap junctions 19 complex of transmembrane proteins in the lateral membrane of each cell forms a pore (a) these are joined across the intercellular space (b) this connects the cytoplasm of adjacent cells, permits the passage of ions & small molecules from cell to cell thus couples cells metabolically and electrically functions to coordinate cellular function; e.g. in a ciliated epithelium, gap junctions coordinate the beating of cilia to ensure their synchronous movement open / close with conformational change also found in e.g. bone cells, cardiac myocytes, smooth muscle cells, where they coordinate cellular function g5.11

1.a 2.a ask yourself two questions: does every cell touch the basement membrane? yes? then it’s “simple”: 1 cell thick found at sites of molecular transfer no? then it’s “stratified”: >1 cell thick found at sites needing protection what is the shape of the cells at the exposed surface? if flat, then it’s “squamous” if height  width, then it’s “cuboidal” if height > width, then it’s “columnar” any specializations of note? microvilli? cilia? goblet cells? include this information in the description mc4.2 1.b 2.b 2.c next previous h1 a classification of epithelia 20
n2.1 next previous h1 classification of epithelia 21

next previous h1 summary 22 to summarize, this emodule has described: where epithelia are located in the body. the structural characteristics of the various classes of epithelia. the functions associated with the different types of epithelia. the relationship of exocrine and endocrine glands to epithelia. the structural modifications found in different epithelia and how they relate to function. the classification system of epithelia. the logic behind the structure / function relationship of epithelia in different locations in the body. how to identify the various classes of epithelia, their cell types and specializations.

(not all descriptions apply.) lines organs of the urinary system. lines organs of the urinary system. lines organs of the urinary system. lines upper digestive tract. surface cell’s shape changes according to filling stage of the organ. surface cell’s shape changes according to filling stage of the organ. surface cell’s shape changes according to filling stage of the organ. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. prevent abrasion and pathogen attack. undergoes keratinization. burn victims succumb their injury due to loss of this layer. submit a b

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: fix this slide

1lumen = the space inside a hollow organ (e.g. stomach, lung) or structure (e.g. blood vessel)

2 avascular = has no blood supply

3 innervated = has a nerve supply

1 trans = across; transcellular molecular movement occurs through cells; i.e. molecules are transported into the cell on one side and then out of the cell on the other side; thus crossing the epithelial barrier

2 para = beside; paracellular molecular movement occurs between cells

1 absorption: the process by which molecules are moved INTO the body

2 secretion: the process by which molecules are moved OUT OF the body

1 shear forces: forces exerted parallel to the epithelial sheet, such as abrasion

2 cytoskeleton = network of fibrous proteins (actin, intermediate filaments, etc.) that provide structural support to cells
to anastomose, is to come together
Cilia vs. Microvilli distinguishing
